# _The Incredible Hulk_ (film)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about the 2008 film. For the 2003 film, see [Hulk
(film)](/wiki/Hulk_\(film\) "Hulk \(film\)"). For other uses, see [The
Incredible Hulk (disambiguation)](/wiki/The_Incredible_Hulk_\(disambiguation\)
"The Incredible Hulk \(disambiguation\)").

_**The Incredible Hulk**_ is a 2008 American [superhero
film](/wiki/Superhero_film "Superhero film") based on the [Marvel
Comics](/wiki/Marvel_Comics "Marvel Comics") character the
[Hulk](/wiki/Hulk_\(comics\) "Hulk \(comics\)"), produced by [Marvel
Studios](/wiki/Marvel_Studios "Marvel Studios") and distributed by [Universal
Pictures](/wiki/Universal_Pictures "Universal Pictures"). It is [the second
film](/wiki/List_of_Marvel_Cinematic_Universe_films "List of Marvel Cinematic
Universe films") in the [Marvel Cinematic
Universe](/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe "Marvel Cinematic Universe") (MCU).
The film was directed by [Louis Leterrier](/wiki/Louis_Leterrier "Louis
Leterrier"), with a screenplay by [Zak Penn](/wiki/Zak_Penn "Zak Penn"). It
stars [Edward Norton](/wiki/Edward_Norton "Edward Norton"), [Liv
Tyler](/wiki/Liv_Tyler "Liv Tyler"), [Tim Roth](/wiki/Tim_Roth "Tim Roth"),
[Tim Blake Nelson](/wiki/Tim_Blake_Nelson "Tim Blake Nelson"), [Ty
Burrell](/wiki/Ty_Burrell "Ty Burrell"), and [William Hurt](/wiki/William_Hurt
"William Hurt"). In _The Incredible Hulk_ , Bruce Banner becomes the Hulk as
an unwitting pawn in a military scheme to reinvigorate the
[supersoldier](/wiki/Supersoldier "Supersoldier") program through gamma
radiation. On the run, he attempts to cure himself of the Hulk before he is
captured by General [Thaddeus Ross](/wiki/Thunderbolt_Ross "Thunderbolt
Ross"), but his worst fears are realized when power-hungry soldier [Emil
Blonsky](/wiki/Abomination_\(comics\) "Abomination \(comics\)") becomes a
similar, but more bestial creature.

After the mixed reception to the 2003 film _[Hulk](/wiki/Hulk_\(film\) "Hulk
\(film\)")_ , Marvel Studios reacquired the rights to the character.
Leterrier, who had expressed interest in directing _[Iron
Man](/wiki/Iron_Man_\(2008_film\) "Iron Man \(2008 film\)")_ , was brought
onboard and Penn began work on a [loose sequel](/wiki/Sequel#Stand-
alone_sequels "Sequel") that would be much closer to the comics and the [1978
television series of the same
name](/wiki/The_Incredible_Hulk_\(1978_TV_series\) "The Incredible Hulk \(1978
TV series\)"). In April 2007, Norton was hired to portray Banner and to
rewrite Penn's screenplay in order to distance itself from the 2003 film and
establish its own identity, although he would go uncredited for his writing.
Filming mostly took place in [Toronto](/wiki/Toronto "Toronto"),
[Ontario](/wiki/Ontario "Ontario"), from July to November 2007. Over 700
visual effects shots were created in post-production using a combination of
[motion capture](/wiki/Motion_capture "Motion capture") and [computer-
generated imagery](/wiki/Computer-generated_imagery "Computer-generated
imagery") to complete the film.

_The Incredible Hulk_ premiered on June 8, 2008 at the [Gibson
Amphitheatre](/wiki/Gibson_Amphitheatre "Gibson Amphitheatre") in [Universal
City, California](/wiki/Universal_City,_California "Universal City,
California") and was released in theaters on June 13, 2008, receiving
generally favorable reviews by critics upon release. Critical praise went to
the improved visuals, action sequences, and the portrayal of the title
character. The film was number one at the [box office](/wiki/Box_office "Box
office"), grossing over $263 million worldwide. Norton was set to reprise the
role of Banner in _[The Avengers](/wiki/The_Avengers_\(2012_film\) "The
Avengers \(2012 film\)")_ and any other MCU installment featuring the
character, but he was ultimately replaced by [Mark Ruffalo](/wiki/Mark_Ruffalo
"Mark Ruffalo"), who has signed on to portray the character in all potential
sequels.

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Incredible_Hulk_\(film\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

At Culver University in Virginia, General [Thunderbolt
Ross](/wiki/Thunderbolt_Ross "Thunderbolt Ross") meets with Dr. [Bruce
Banner](/wiki/Bruce_Banner "Bruce Banner"), the colleague and boyfriend of his
daughter [Betty](/wiki/Betty_Ross "Betty Ross"), regarding an experiment that
Ross claims is meant to make humans immune to [gamma
radiation](/wiki/Gamma_radiation "Gamma radiation"). The experiment — part of
a [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") era "super soldier"
program that Ross hopes to recreate — fails, and the exposure to gamma
radiation causes Banner to transform into the [Hulk](/wiki/Hulk_\(comics\)
"Hulk \(comics\)") for brief periods of time, whenever his heart rate rises
above 200. The Hulk destroys the lab and injures or kills the people inside.
Banner becomes a fugitive from the U.S. military and Ross in particular, who
wants to weaponize the Hulk process.

Five years later,[N 1] Banner works at a bottling factory in
[Rocinha](/wiki/Rocinha "Rocinha"), [Rio de Janeiro](/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro "Rio
de Janeiro") in Brazil, while searching for a cure for his condition. On the
Internet, he collaborates with a colleague he knows only as "Mr. Blue", and to
whom he is "Mr. Green". He is also learning [Yoga](/wiki/Yoga "Yoga")
techniques to help keep control, and has not transformed in five months. After
Banner cuts his finger, a drop of his blood falls into a bottle, and is
eventually ingested by an elderly consumer in [Milwaukee,
Wisconsin](/wiki/Milwaukee,_Wisconsin "Milwaukee, Wisconsin"), giving him
gamma sickness. Using the bottle to track down Banner, Ross sends a special
forces team, led by Russian-born British [Royal Marine](/wiki/Royal_Marine
"Royal Marine") [Emil Blonsky](/wiki/Abomination_\(comics\) "Abomination
\(comics\)"), to capture him. Banner transforms into the Hulk and defeats
Blonsky's team. After Ross explains how Banner became the Hulk, Blonsky agrees
to be injected with a small amount of a similar serum, which gives him
enhanced speed, strength, agility, and healing, but also begins to deform his
skeleton and impair his judgment.

Banner returns to Culver University and reunites with Betty, who is dating
psychiatrist [Leonard Samson](/wiki/Doc_Samson "Doc Samson"). Banner is
attacked a second time by Ross and Blonsky's forces, tipped off by the
suspicious Samson, causing him to again transform into the Hulk. The ensuing
battle outside the university proves to be futile for Ross' forces and they
eventually retreat, though Blonsky, whose sanity is starting to falter, boldly
attacks and mocks the Hulk. The Hulk seemingly kills Blonsky and flees with
Betty. After the Hulk reverts to Banner, he and Betty go on the run, and
Banner contacts Mr. Blue, who urges them to meet him in New York City. Mr.
Blue is actually cellular biologist Dr. [Samuel
Sterns](/wiki/Leader_\(comics\) "Leader \(comics\)"), who tells Banner he has
developed a possible antidote to Banner's condition. After a successful test,
he warns Banner that the antidote may only reverse each individual
transformation. Sterns reveals he has [synthesized](/wiki/Organic_synthesis
"Organic synthesis") Banner's blood samples, which Banner sent from Brazil,
into a large supply, with the intention of applying its "limitless potential"
to medicine. Fearful of the Hulk's power falling into the military's hands,
Banner wishes to destroy the blood supply.

Meanwhile, Blonsky is revealed to have survived the earlier battle at Culver
University and has completely healed. He joins Ross' forces for a third
attempt to take Banner into custody. They succeed and Banner, along with
Betty, are taken away in a helicopter. Blonsky stays behind and orders Sterns
to inject him with Banner's blood, as he covets the Hulk's power. Sterns warns
that the combination of the super-soldier formula and Banner's blood may cause
him to become an "abomination", but Blonsky insists. The experiment mutates
Blonsky into a creature with size and strength surpassing that of the Hulk,
but drives him mad. He attacks Sterns, who gets some of Banner's blood in a
cut on his forehead, causing him to begin mutating as well. Blonsky then
rampages through [Harlem](/wiki/Harlem "Harlem"). Realizing that the Hulk is
the only one who can stop Blonsky, Banner convinces Ross to release him. He
jumps from Ross' helicopter and transforms after hitting the ground. After a
long and brutal battle through Harlem, the Hulk defeats Blonsky. After having
a small, peaceful moment with Betty, the Hulk flees from New York.

A month later, Banner is in [Bella Coola, British
Columbia](/wiki/Bella_Coola,_British_Columbia "Bella Coola, British
Columbia"). Instead of trying to suppress his transformation, he successfully
transforms in a controlled manner. In a final scene, [Tony
Stark](/wiki/Iron_Man "Iron Man") approaches Ross at a local bar and informs
him [a team](/wiki/The_Avengers_\(2012_film\) "The Avengers \(2012 film\)") is
being put together.

##
Cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Incredible_Hulk_\(film\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cast")]

  * [Edward Norton](/wiki/Edward_Norton "Edward Norton") as [Bruce Banner / Hulk](/wiki/Hulk_\(comics\) "Hulk \(comics\)"):  
A [nuclear physicist](/wiki/Nuclear_physics "Nuclear physics") and
[biochemist](/wiki/Biochemist "Biochemist") at Culver University who, because
of exposure to [gamma radiation](/wiki/Gamma_radiation "Gamma radiation"),
transforms into an enormous green humanoid monster when enraged or agitated.
[David Duchovny](/wiki/David_Duchovny "David Duchovny") was a front-runner for
the film before Norton's casting,[7] while Louis Leterrier's original choice
for the role was [Mark Ruffalo](/wiki/Mark_Ruffalo "Mark Ruffalo"), who would
later play Banner in the [Marvel Cinematic
Universe](/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe "Marvel Cinematic Universe").[8]
[Gale Anne Hurd](/wiki/Gale_Anne_Hurd "Gale Anne Hurd") recalled Norton's
portrayals of duality in _[Primal Fear](/wiki/Primal_Fear_\(film\) "Primal
Fear \(film\)")_ and _[Fight Club](/wiki/Fight_Club "Fight Club")_ ,[9] while
Norton reminded [Kevin Feige](/wiki/Kevin_Feige "Kevin Feige") of [Bill
Bixby](/wiki/Bill_Bixby "Bill Bixby"), who played Banner in the [TV
series](/wiki/The_Incredible_Hulk_\(1978_TV_series\) "The Incredible Hulk
\(1978 TV series\)").[10] Lou Ferrigno, who played the Hulk with Bixby,
remarked Norton "has a similar physique [and a] similar personality".[11]
Norton was a _Hulk_ fan, citing the first comic appearances, the Bixby TV
show, and Bruce Jones' run on the comic, as his favorite depictions of the
character.[12] He had expressed interest in the role for the first film.[13]
He initially turned down the part, recalling "there [was] the wince factor or
the defensive part of you that recoils at what the bad version of what that
would be", as he felt the previous film "strayed far afield from a story that
was familiar to people, [...] which is a fugitive story". When he met
Leterrier and Marvel, he liked their vision, and believed they were looking to
him to guide the project. Thus, Norton rewrote the script.[14] "Edward's
script has given Bruce's story real gravitas," Leterrier said. "Admittedly I'm
not the most adult director, but just because we're making a superhero movie
it doesn't have to just appeal to 13-year-old boys. Ed and I both see
superheroes as the new [Greek gods](/wiki/Greek_pantheon "Greek
pantheon")."[15] Additionally, [Lou Ferrigno](/wiki/Lou_Ferrigno "Lou
Ferrigno") provides vocal performance as the Hulk. During the 2008 [New York
Comic Con](/wiki/New_York_Comic_Con "New York Comic Con") Leterrier publicly
offered Ferrigno the chance to voice the Hulk for the film.[16] This marks the
third time Ferrigno portrayed the Hulk, having also voiced the character in
the [1996 animated series](/wiki/The_Incredible_Hulk_\(1996_TV_series\) "The
Incredible Hulk \(1996 TV series\)"). Originally, the Hulk's only line was
"Betty" at the film's ending, which would have been his first word. Leterrier
was aware that fans wanted him to speak normally, and added "leave me alone"
and "Hulk smash!" The latter line received cheers during a screening he
attended.[17] Ferrigno also has a cameo in the film as a security guard who is
bribed by Banner with a pizza.[18]

  * [Liv Tyler](/wiki/Liv_Tyler "Liv Tyler") as [Betty Ross](/wiki/Betty_Ross "Betty Ross"):  
A [cellular biologist](/wiki/Cellular_biology "Cellular biology") and Bruce's
girlfriend, from whom he is separated as a result of his condition. Tyler was
attracted to the love story in the script, and was a fan of the TV show,
because of the "humanity and what [Banner] is going through".[12] She was
called about the role while driving to her home, and she accepted the part
after a day without reading the script.[19] Tyler and Norton spent hours
discussing Bruce and Betty's life before he became the Hulk.[20] She said
filming the part "was very physical, which was fun",[21] and compared her
performance to "a deer caught in the headlights", because of Betty's shock at
Bruce's unexpected return into her life.[20]

  * [Tim Roth](/wiki/Tim_Roth "Tim Roth") as [Emil Blonsky / Abomination](/wiki/Abomination_\(comics\) "Abomination \(comics\)"):  
A Russian-born officer in the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United
Kingdom")'s [Royal Marines Commandos](/wiki/Royal_Marines_Commandos "Royal
Marines Commandos") loaned to Ross who, lusting for the Hulk's power, is
injected with various serums that transforms him into a near-skeletal humanoid
monster more powerful than the Hulk himself. Roth said he took the part to
please his sons, who are comic-book superhero fans. As a teenager, Roth was a
fan of the 1970s TV series, and he also found Leterrier's ideas "very dark and
very interesting". Roth started watching the 2003 film to prepare for the
part, but stopped as he did not want to be caught up in the controversy over
its quality, and to compare himself to it.[22] It was Roth who suggested
Blonsky be a soldier, whereas in the comics he was a [KGB](/wiki/KGB "KGB")
agent.[23] Leterrier was a fan of Roth's work, and felt "it's great watching a
normal [Cockney](/wiki/Cockney "Cockney") boy become a superhero!",[15] but
Marvel and Norton were initially reluctant to cast him.[24] Before he was cast
in _[Punisher: War Zone](/wiki/Punisher:_War_Zone "Punisher: War Zone")_ ,
[Ray Stevenson](/wiki/Ray_Stevenson_\(actor\) "Ray Stevenson \(actor\)") was
in discussions for the role.[25] Roth prepared for the part by learning to
fire guns and break into rooms with two experts.[23] Roth found it tough
shooting the chases, because to show Blonsky's aging he could not work
out.[20] He especially found it difficult to run while pulled with a harness,
which was used to show the injected Blonsky's 30–40 mile per hour running
abilities.[26] [Cyril Raffaelli](/wiki/Cyril_Raffaelli "Cyril Raffaelli")
performed some of Roth's stunts.[9] Roth enjoyed the [motion
capture](/wiki/Motion_capture "Motion capture"), which reminded him of [fringe
theatre](/wiki/Fringe_theatre "Fringe theatre"), and he hired his trainer from
_[Planet of the Apes](/wiki/Planet_of_the_Apes_\(2001_film\) "Planet of the
Apes \(2001 film\)")_ to aid him in portraying the monster's movement.[20]

  * [Tim Blake Nelson](/wiki/Tim_Blake_Nelson "Tim Blake Nelson") as [Samuel Sterns](/wiki/Leader_\(comics\) "Leader \(comics\)"): The cellular biologist who develops a possible antidote to Banner's condition. Towards the end of the film, Sterns is exposed to some substance that begins his transformation into [Leader](/wiki/Leader_\(comics\) "Leader \(comics\)").
  * [Ty Burrell](/wiki/Ty_Burrell "Ty Burrell") as [Leonard Samson](/wiki/Doc_Samson "Doc Samson"):  
A psychiatrist in a relationship with Betty during Bruce's absence. Burrell
had performed with Norton in the [off Broadway](/wiki/Off_Broadway "Off
Broadway") play _[Burn This](/wiki/Burn_This "Burn This")_ in 2003, and when
Leterrier met him, he recognized Burrell as the "jerk" from the 2004 _[Dawn of
the Dead](/wiki/Dawn_of_the_Dead_\(2004_film\) "Dawn of the Dead \(2004
film\)")_ remake,[27] which was how Samson was characterized in the script
before Norton's rewrote it.[28]

  * [William Hurt](/wiki/William_Hurt "William Hurt") as [Thaddeus "Thunderbolt" Ross](/wiki/Thunderbolt_Ross "Thunderbolt Ross"):  
Betty's arrogant father, who has dedicated himself to capturing the Hulk.
Leterrier cast Hurt because "Ross is more physical, more explosive in this
movie, and no actor goes from zero to 100 as well as William."[15] He compared
Ross to [Captain Ahab](/wiki/Ahab_\(Moby-Dick\) "Ahab \(Moby-Dick\)").[24] The
Hulk is Hurt's favorite superhero, and his son is also a big fan of the
character. Hurt found production very different from the typical "pure
anxiety" of a studio film, finding it more akin to an independent film.[29] He
described Ross as "humiliated by Hulk's conscience: he actually sees and
recognizes that it's more developed than his own, even though he's a patriot
and a warrior for his country. He's sacrificed [much] for that purpose, but at
the expense at times of his humanity – which he occasionally recovers."[30] In
June 2015, when reflecting on how his reprisal in _[Captain America: Civil
War](/wiki/Captain_America:_Civil_War "Captain America: Civil War")_ was
different from this film, Hurt said, "What I created [for _The Incredible
Hulk_] was a Ross who was right out of the graphic novel type of thing, where
he was as much of a cartoon, in a way, as the monsters were. His ego was just
as big and his problems were just as big. I really did do that consciously. I
created a General Ross before which created a verisimilitude for the monsters,
by making him a human monster. I worked really hard on the makeup and the
exaggerated behavior and things like that and a controlled psychosis."[31]
[Sam Elliott](/wiki/Sam_Elliott "Sam Elliott") had expressed interest in
reprising the role from the first _Hulk_ film.[32]

[Robert Downey, Jr.](/wiki/Robert_Downey,_Jr. "Robert Downey, Jr.") has an
uncredited cameo as Tony Stark at the end of the film. Downey appeared as a
favor to [Marvel Studios](/wiki/Marvel_Studios "Marvel Studios"), which he
acknowledged as a smart move on Marvel's part, because when he was promoting
his film he would also have to mention their other production.[33] Hulk co-
creator [Stan Lee](/wiki/Stan_Lee "Stan Lee") cameos as a man who becomes ill
when drinking the soda poisoned by Banner's blood. [Michael K.
Williams](/wiki/Michael_K._Williams "Michael K. Williams") appears as a Harlem
bystander, a role that was written for him by Norton, who is a fan of _[The
Wire](/wiki/The_Wire_\(TV_series\) "The Wire \(TV series\)")_.[34] [Paul
Soles](/wiki/Paul_Soles "Paul Soles"), who voiced Banner in the 1966 _[The
Marvel Superheroes](/wiki/The_Marvel_Superheroes "The Marvel Superheroes")_
cartoon, appears as Stanley, a kindly pizza restaurant owner who helps Banner.
Additionally, the late [Bill Bixby](/wiki/Bill_Bixby "Bill Bixby") appears, in
a scene on his TV comedy-drama _[The Courtship of Eddie's
Father](/wiki/The_Courtship_of_Eddie%27s_Father "The Courtship of Eddie's
Father")_ on a television Banner is watching at the beginning of the film.
[Rickson Gracie](/wiki/Rickson_Gracie "Rickson Gracie") has a small role as
Bruce Banner's martial arts instructor, despite his [Brazilian Jiu-
Jitsu](/wiki/Brazilian_Jiu-Jitsu "Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu") background, he is
credited as an [Aikido](/wiki/Aikido "Aikido") instructor. [Peter
Mensah](/wiki/Peter_Mensah "Peter Mensah") plays a small role as General Joe
Gellar, one of General Ross' military friends/associates. [Martin
Starr](/wiki/Martin_Starr "Martin Starr") plays a college student, credited as
"Computer Nerd" and identified as [Amadeus Cho](/wiki/Amadeus_Cho "Amadeus
Cho") in the novelization for the film.[35] Hulk supporting characters, [Jim
Wilson](/wiki/Jim_Wilson_\(comics\) "Jim Wilson \(comics\)") and [Jack
McGee](/wiki/Jack_McGee_\(Marvel\) "Jack McGee \(Marvel\)"), make cameo
appearances as Culver University students played by P.J. Kerr and Nicholas
Rose, respectively.[36]

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Incredible_Hulk_\(film\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

###
Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Incredible_Hulk_\(film\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Development")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cc/IncredibleHulkTVreference.jpg/200px-
IncredibleHulkTVreference.jpg)](/wiki/File:IncredibleHulkTVreference.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:IncredibleHulkTVreference.jpg "Enlarge")

_The Incredible Hulk_ is influenced by the TV series of the same name. Above
is Edward Norton, and below is Bill Bixby, both sitting in a similar machine.

At the time of the release of [Ang Lee](/wiki/Ang_Lee "Ang Lee")'s
_[Hulk](/wiki/Hulk_\(film\) "Hulk \(film\)")_ , screenwriter [James
Schamus](/wiki/James_Schamus "James Schamus") was planning a sequel, featuring
the Grey Hulk. He was also considering the Leader and the Abomination as
villains.[37] Marvel wanted the Abomination because he would be an actual
threat to the Hulk, unlike General Ross.[38] During the filming of _Hulk_ ,
producer Avi Arad had a target May 2005 theatrical release date.[39] On
January 18, 2006 Arad confirmed Marvel Studios would be providing the money
for _The Incredible Hulk_ 's production budget, with Universal
distributing,[40] because Universal did not meet the deadline for filming a
sequel.[7] Marvel felt it would be better to deviate from Ang Lee's style to
continue the franchise, arguing his film was like a [parallel
universe](/wiki/Parallel_universe_\(fiction\) "Parallel universe \(fiction\)")
[one-shot](/wiki/One-shot_\(comics\) "One-shot \(comics\)") comic book, and
their next film needed to be, in Kevin Feige's words, "_really_ starting the
Marvel Hulk franchise". Producer Gale Anne Hurd also felt the film had to meet
what "everyone expects to see from having read the comics and seen the TV
series".[20]

### Pre-
production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Incredible_Hulk_\(film\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Pre-production")]

Louis Leterrier, who enjoyed the TV series as a child and liked the first
film,[9][20] had expressed interest in directing the _[Iron
Man](/wiki/Iron_Man_\(2008_film\) "Iron Man \(2008 film\)")_ film adaptation.
[Jon Favreau](/wiki/Jon_Favreau "Jon Favreau") had taken that project, so
Marvel offered him the Hulk. Leterrier was reluctant as he was unsure if he
could replicate Lee's style, but Marvel explained that was not their
intent.[41] Leterrier's primary inspiration was [Jeph Loeb](/wiki/Jeph_Loeb
"Jeph Loeb") and [Tim Sale](/wiki/Tim_Sale_\(artist\) "Tim Sale \(artist\)")'s
_Hulk: Gray_ (a retelling of the character's first appearance). He replicated
every comic book panel that he pinned-up during pre-production, from the many
comics he browsed, in the final film.[9] Leterrier said that he planned to
show Bruce Banner's struggle with the monster within him,[42] while Feige
added the film would explore "that element of wish fulfillment, of overcoming
an injustice or a bully and tapping into a strength that you didn't quite
realize you had in yourself".[43] Arad also said the film would be "a lot more
of a love story between Bruce Banner and Betty Ross".[44]

[Zak Penn](/wiki/Zak_Penn "Zak Penn"), who wrote a draft of the first film in
1996, said the film would follow up _Hulk_ , but stressed it would be more
tonally similar to the TV show and [Bruce Jones](/wiki/Bruce_Jones_\(comics\)
"Bruce Jones \(comics\)")' [run on the
comic](/wiki/Hulk_\(comics\)#Bibliography "Hulk \(comics\)"). He compared his
script to _[Aliens](/wiki/Aliens_\(film\) "Aliens \(film\)")_ , which was a
very different film from _[Alien](/wiki/Alien_\(film\) "Alien \(film\)")_ ,
but still in the same continuity.[13] He included two scenes from his 1996
script: Banner jumping from a helicopter to trigger a transformation, and
realizing he is unable to have sex with Betty.[45] After the studio rejected a
treatment by another screenwriter in 2006, Penn wrote three drafts before
departing in early 2007 to promote his film _[The
Grand](/wiki/The_Grand_\(film\) "The Grand \(film\)")_.[46] Norton, that
April, began discussions to play Banner, and arranged a deal that included him
as both an actor and a writer, with a screenplay draft he was contractually
obligated to turn in within a month. He did so, and continued to polish his
draft as late as halfway through principal photography.[46] In November 2006,
a June 13, 2008 release date was set.[47] Leterrier acknowledged the only
remaining similarity between the two films was Bruce hiding in South
America,[9] and that the film was a unique reboot, as generally audiences
would have expected another forty-minute origin story.[48] There were previous
discussions to set the first act in Thailand.[49] Leterrier felt audiences
were left restless waiting for the character to arrive in Ang Lee's film.[48]
Feige commented, "we didn't want to tell the origin story again, because we
thought people were so familiar with it, which is why we didn't tell that...
One reason we made _Incredible Hulk_ was to get Hulk into the [[Marvel
Cinematic Universe](/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe "Marvel Cinematic
Universe")] canon."[50]

Shortly after the release of _The Incredible Hulk_ , Gale Anne Hurd commented
on the uncertainty of its relationship with Ang Lee's _Hulk_ film. "We
couldn't quite figure out how to term this ... It's kind of a reboot and it's
kind of sequel." Hurd said that "requel", a
[portmanteau](/wiki/Portmanteau_word "Portmanteau word") of "reboot" and
"sequel", was a "perfect" description for the film.[51] Norton explained his
decision to ignore Lee's origin story: "I don't even like the phrase 'origin
story', and I don't think in great literature and great films that explaining
the roots of the story doesn't mean it comes in the beginning."[12] "Audiences
know this story," he added, "[so] deal with it artfully." He wanted to "have
revelations even in the third act about what set this whole thing in
motion".[14] The new origin story references [Ultimate
Marvel](/wiki/Ultimate_Marvel "Ultimate Marvel")'s take on the Hulk, which
also had him created in an attempt to make super soldiers.[52] Norton removed
[Rick Jones](/wiki/Rick_Jones_\(comics\) "Rick Jones \(comics\)") and toned
down [S.H.I.E.L.D.](/wiki/S.H.I.E.L.D. "S.H.I.E.L.D.")'s presence.[20] He also
added the scene where Banner attempts to extract a cure from a flower and his
e-mailing with Samuel Sterns,[45] which references Bruce Jones' story.[53]
Norton rewrote scenes every day.[22] Ultimately, the [Writers Guild of
America](/wiki/Writers_Guild_of_America "Writers Guild of America") decided to
credit the script solely to Penn,[54] who argued Norton had not dramatically
changed his script. Journalist [Anne
Thompson](/wiki/Anne_Thompson_\(film_critic\) "Anne Thompson \(film critic\)")
explained "The Guild tends to favor plot, structure and pre-existing
characters over dialogue."[45] Penn said in 2008, "I wasn't happy with
[Norton] coming to Comic-Con saying that he wrote the script."[55] Before
either Penn and Norton joined the project, an anonymous screenwriter wrote a
draft and lobbied for credit.[45]

###
Filming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Incredible_Hulk_\(film\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Filming")]

Leterrier had to direct four [units](/wiki/Second_unit "Second unit") with a
broken foot.[15] Filming began on July 9, 2007. Shooting primarily took place
in [Toronto](/wiki/Toronto "Toronto"), because mayor [David
Miller](/wiki/David_Miller_\(Canadian_politician\) "David Miller \(Canadian
politician\)") is a Hulk fan and promised to be very helpful to the crew when
closing [Yonge Street](/wiki/Yonge_Street "Yonge Street") for four nights in
September to shoot Hulk and Blonsky's climactic fight. Despite messing up the
street with explosives and overturned burning vehicles, the crew would clean
it up within twenty minutes so business could continue as normal each day.[56]
The first action sequence shot was the Culver University battle, which was
filmed at the [University of Toronto](/wiki/University_of_Toronto "University
of Toronto") and [Morningside Park](/wiki/Morningside_Park_\(Toronto\)
"Morningside Park \(Toronto\)"). The filmmakers built a glass wall over a
walkway at the University for when the soldiers trap Banner inside to smoke
him out.[26] There was also shooting in the [Financial
District](/wiki/Financial_District,_Toronto "Financial District,
Toronto").[27] A factory in [Hamilton, Ontario](/wiki/Hamilton,_Ontario
"Hamilton, Ontario"), which was due for demolition, was the interior of the
Brazilian factory. The site's underground floors were used for Ross' military
command center.[56] The crew also shot part of the Hulk and Blonsky's fight on
a [backlot](/wiki/Backlot "Backlot") in Hamilton.[57] Other Canadian locations
included [CFB Trenton](/wiki/CFB_Trenton "CFB Trenton") and a glacier in Bella
Coola, British Columbia.[27] Afterwards, there was a week-long shoot in [New
York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") and two weeks in Rio de
Janeiro.[58] While there, the crew shot at Rocinha,
[Lapa](/wiki/Lapa,_Rio_de_Janeiro "Lapa, Rio de Janeiro"), [Tijuca
Forest](/wiki/Tijuca_Forest "Tijuca Forest") and [Santa
Teresa](/wiki/Santa_Teresa_\(Rio_de_Janeiro\) "Santa Teresa \(Rio de
Janeiro\)"). Filming concluded in November after eighty-eight days of
filming.[27]

_The Incredible Hulk_ joined Toronto's Green-Screen initiative, to help cut
[carbon emissions](/wiki/Carbon_emissions "Carbon emissions") and waste
created during filming.[59] Producer Gale Anne Hurd acknowledged the Hulk,
being green, was a popular environmental analogy, and Norton himself was an
environmentalist. Hybrid and fuel efficient vehicles were used, with low
sulfur diesel as their energy source. The construction department used a
sustainably harvested, locally sourced [yellow pine](/wiki/Pinus_echinata
"Pinus echinata") instead of [lauan](/wiki/Decorative_plywood "Decorative
plywood") for the sets, and also used zero-or
low-[VOC](/wiki/Volatile_Organic_Compounds "Volatile Organic Compounds")
paint. The wood was generally recycled or given to environmental
organizations, and paint cans were handed to waste management. In addition,
they used cloth bags, biodegradable food containers, china and silverware food
utensils, a stainless steel mug for each production crew member, a contractor
who removed bins, recycled paper, biodegradable soap and cleaners in the
trailers and production offices, and the sound department used rechargeable
batteries.[27] _The Incredible Hulk_ became the first blockbuster film to
receive the [Environmental Media
Association](/wiki/Environmental_Media_Association "Environmental Media
Association")'s Green Seal, which is displayed during the end credits.[60]

### Post-
production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Incredible_Hulk_\(film\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Post-production")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/MovieAbomination.jpg/220px-
MovieAbomination.jpg)](/wiki/File:MovieAbomination.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:MovieAbomination.jpg "Enlarge")

Leterrier's finished redesign of the Abomination.

Leterrier cited [Andy Serkis](/wiki/Andy_Serkis "Andy Serkis")' [motion
capture](/wiki/Motion_capture "Motion capture") portrayals of
[Gollum](/wiki/Gollum "Gollum") and [King Kong](/wiki/King_Kong "King Kong")
in _[The Lord of the Rings](/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings_\(film_series\) "The
Lord of the Rings \(film series\)")_ and _[King
Kong](/wiki/King_Kong_\(2005_film\) "King Kong \(2005 film\)")_ ,
respectively, as the standard he was aiming for.[41] Norton and Roth filmed
2500 takes of different movements the monsters would make (such as the Hulk's
"thunder claps").[27] [Phosphorescent](/wiki/Phosphorescent "Phosphorescent")
[face paint](/wiki/Face_paint "Face paint") applied to the actors' faces and
[strobe lighting](/wiki/Strobe_light "Strobe light") would help record the
most subtle mannerisms into the computer.[61] Others including [Cyril
Raffaelli](/wiki/Cyril_Raffaelli "Cyril Raffaelli") provided motion capture
for stunts and fights,[23] after the main actors had done video
referencing.[62] Leterrier hired [Rhythm and
Hues](/wiki/Rhythm_and_Hues_Studios "Rhythm and Hues Studios") to provide the
CGI, rather than [Industrial Light & Magic](/wiki/Industrial_Light_%26_Magic
"Industrial Light & Magic") who created the visual effects for Ang Lee's
_Hulk_. Visual effect company, [Image Engine](/wiki/Image_Engine "Image
Engine"), spent over a year working on a shot where Banner's gamma-irradiated
blood falls through three factory floors into a bottle.[63] Overall 700
effects shots were created. Motion capture aided in placing and timing of
movements, but overall [key frame](/wiki/Key_frame "Key frame") animation by
Rhythm and Hues provided the necessary "finesse [and] superhero quality".[64]
Many of the animators and Leterrier himself provided video reference for the
climactic fight.[26]

[Dale Keown](/wiki/Dale_Keown "Dale Keown")'s comic book artwork of the Hulk
was an inspiration for his design.[41] Leterrier felt the first Hulk had "too
much fat [and] the proportions were a little off". He explained, "The Hulk is
beyond perfect so there is zero grams of fat, all chiseled, and his muscle and
strength defines this creature so he's like a tank."[41] [Visual effects
supervisor](/wiki/Visual_effects_supervisor "Visual effects supervisor") Kurt
Williams envisioned the Hulk's physique as a [linebacker](/wiki/Linebacker
"Linebacker") rather than a [bodybuilder](/wiki/Bodybuilder "Bodybuilder"). A
height of nine feet was chosen for the character as they did not want him to
be too inhuman. To make him more expressive, computer programs controlling the
inflation of his muscles and saturation of skin color were created. Williams
cited [flushing](/wiki/Flushing_\(physiology\) "Flushing \(physiology\)") as
an example of humans' skin color being influenced by their emotions.[27] The
animators felt green blood would make his skin become darker rather than
lighter, and his skin tones, depending on lighting, either resemble an
[olive](/wiki/Olive "Olive") or even gray [slate](/wiki/Slate "Slate").[61]
His animation model was completed without the effects company's full knowledge
of what he would be required to do: he was rigged to do whatever they
imagined, in case the model was to be used for _The Avengers_ film.[64] The
Hulk's medium-length hair was modeled on [Mike Deodato](/wiki/Mike_Deodato
"Mike Deodato")'s art.[64] He originally had a [crew cut](/wiki/Crew_cut "Crew
cut"), but Leterrier decided flopping hair imbued him with more character.[62]
Leterrier cited _[An American Werewolf in
London](/wiki/An_American_Werewolf_in_London "An American Werewolf in
London")_ as the inspiration for Banner's transformation, wanting to show how
painful it was for him to change.[65] As a nod to the live action TV series,
Banner's eyes change color first when he transforms.[66] Leterrier changed the
Abomination's design from the comics because he felt the audience would
question why he resembled a fish or a reptile, instead of "an
[über](/wiki/%C3%9Cber "Über")-human" like the Hulk. Rather, his hideousness
is derived from being injected multiple times into his skin, muscles and
bones; creating a creature with a protruding spine and sharp bones that he can
use to stab. His green skin is pale, and reflects light, so it appears orange
because of surrounding fire during the climactic battle.[24] The motion
capture performers, including Roth, tried to make the character behave less
gracefully than the Hulk. They modeled his posture and the way he turns his
head on a shark.[38] The character also shares Roth's tattoos.[67] A height of
eleven feet was chosen for the character.[27] Leterrier tried to work in the
character's pointed ears, but realized the Hulk would bite them off (using the
example of [Mike Tyson](/wiki/Mike_Tyson "Mike Tyson") when he fought [Evander
Holyfield](/wiki/Evander_Holyfield "Evander Holyfield")), and felt ignoring
that would make the Hulk come across as stupid.[68]

Leterrier had planned to use [prosthetic makeup](/wiki/Prosthetic_makeup
"Prosthetic makeup") and [animatronics](/wiki/Animatronic "Animatronic") to
complement the [computer-generated imagery](/wiki/Computer-generated_imagery
"Computer-generated imagery") that was solely used in the previous film.[69]
The make-up artists who worked on _[X-Men: The Last
Stand](/wiki/X-Men:_The_Last_Stand "X-Men: The Last Stand")_ were set to
portray Blonsky's gradual transformation,[22] which Zak Penn said would
portray Blonsky "not [being] used to having these properties. Like he's much
heavier, and we talked about how when he walks down the sidewalk, his weight
destroys the sidewalk and he's tripping. [It's all about] the humanization of
these kinds of superhero characters, showing the effects physics may actually
have on [them]."[70] Tom Woodruff, Jr. of Amalgamated Dynamics (who created
all the costumes for the _[Alien](/wiki/Alien_\(franchise\) "Alien
\(franchise\)")_ films since _[Alien 3](/wiki/Alien_3 "Alien 3")_) was in
negotiations, and created two busts of the Hulk and prosthetic hands to act as
stand-ins for the character. A full animatronic was never created as it was
decided it would complicate production to set up shots for a puppet and then a
computer graphic.[71] An animatronic was used for Sterns' mutating head,
however.[57] Destruction was mostly done practically. A model of a bottling
machine was smashed through a wall for when the Hulk escapes the factory. The
filmmakers used steam and [dry ice](/wiki/Dry_ice "Dry ice") for the gas used
to smoke out the Hulk, and they destroyed a real Humvee by dropping a weight
on it when shooting the Culver University battle. Pipes blew fire for when the
Hulk strikes down the computer-generated helicopter. When Banner falls from
the helicopter to trigger the Hulk into fighting the Abomination, Norton was
attached to a surface held by a bar which turned 90 degrees while the camera
was pulled to the ceiling to simulate falling. Leterrier jokingly remarked
that making Norton fall that distance would obviously render him unable to
act.[26]

##
Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Incredible_Hulk_\(film\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Music")]

Further information: [The Incredible Hulk
(soundtrack)](/wiki/The_Incredible_Hulk_\(soundtrack\) "The Incredible Hulk
\(soundtrack\)") and [Music of the Marvel Cinematic
Universe](/wiki/Music_of_the_Marvel_Cinematic_Universe "Music of the Marvel
Cinematic Universe")

The score for the film was composed by [Craig
Armstrong](/wiki/Craig_Armstrong_\(composer\) "Craig Armstrong \(composer\)"),
who was the [arranger](/wiki/Arrangement "Arrangement") for [Massive
Attack](/wiki/Massive_Attack "Massive Attack"), a band Leterrier was fond of
and had collaborated with on the 2005 film
_[Unleashed](/wiki/Unleashed_\(film\) "Unleashed \(film\)")_. Armstrong was
his first choice, which surprised Marvel, not knowing if he had scored an
action film (he did compose 2001's _[Kiss of the
Dragon](/wiki/Kiss_of_the_Dragon "Kiss of the Dragon")_).[72] At Leterrier's
suggestion, the soundtrack was released on a two-disc album, which Armstrong
thought was a joke until he compiled the album and Marvel asked him why they
were given only one disc.[73] The films score borrow's [Joe
Harnell](/wiki/Joe_Harnell "Joe Harnell")'s theme "The Lonely Man" from the
1978 _Incredible Hulk_ television series.[74]

##
Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Incredible_Hulk_\(film\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Release")]

_The Incredible Hulk_ premiered on June 8, 2008 at the [Gibson
Amphitheatre](/wiki/Gibson_Amphitheatre "Gibson Amphitheatre") in [Universal
City, California](/wiki/Universal_City,_California "Universal City,
California")[75] and was released in theaters on June 13.[47]

###
Editing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Incredible_Hulk_\(film\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Editing")]

Seventy minutes of footage, mostly dealing with the origin, were not included
in the final cut.[28] Much of this back-story was unscripted and the
filmmakers were never sure of including it into the final cut, and had
considered releasing some of these clips on the internet.[18] Editor [Kyle
Cooper](/wiki/Kyle_Cooper "Kyle Cooper"), creator of the Marvel logo (with the
flipping pages) and the montage detailing Iron Man's biography in that film,
edited together much of this footage into the opening credits.[18] Leterrier
explained a negative test screening, where flashbacks were placed across the
film that the audience found too similar to _Hulk_ , had resulted in
compressing these to the film's start.[28] This replaced the original opening,
where Banner comes to the [Arctic](/wiki/Arctic "Arctic") to commit
[suicide](/wiki/Suicide "Suicide"). When the scene ends, in an instant the
frozen body of [Captain America](/wiki/Captain_America "Captain America") is
partially seen in the ice. Leterrier said he did not want this scene to be
lost amid the opening montage.[28]

Norton and Leterrier disputed with the producers over the final running time:
they wanted it to be near 135 minutes, while the producers wanted the film to
be under two hours. This was made public, and rumors spread that Norton "made
it clear he won't cooperate with publicity plans if he's not happy with the
final product".[76] Norton dismissed this, "Our healthy process [of
collaboration], which is and should be a private matter, was misrepresented
publicly as a 'dispute', seized on by people looking for a good story, and has
been distorted to such a degree that it risks distracting from the film
itself, which Marvel, Universal and I refuse to let happen. It has always been
my firm conviction that films should speak for themselves and that knowing too
much about how they are made diminishes the magic of watching them."[77]

###
Marketing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Incredible_Hulk_\(film\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Marketing")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Louis-Leterrier-
Incroyable-Hulk-2.JPG/170px-Louis-Leterrier-Incroyable-
Hulk-2.JPG)](/wiki/File:Louis-Leterrier-Incroyable-Hulk-2.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Louis-Leterrier-Incroyable-Hulk-2.JPG "Enlarge")

[Louis Leterrier](/wiki/Louis_Leterrier "Louis Leterrier") promoting the film
in [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris") in July 2008.

"We know the Hulk from 2003 didn't satisfy the fans, and we had to acknowledge
that. We emphasized the passion that fans still have for this character and
that this is the movie people have always wanted."

—Stephanie Sperber, executive vice-president of Universal Studios
Partnerships[78]

Effort was made to promote the story as having a romance and a physical
antagonist, and the title was used for promotional puns (such as
[7-Eleven](/wiki/7-Eleven "7-Eleven")'s "Incredible Gulp" slurpees, and
"Incredible Dad" themed [Father's Day](/wiki/Father%27s_Day "Father's Day")
gifts at [Kmart](/wiki/Kmart "Kmart")). [Burger King](/wiki/Burger_King
"Burger King") also promoted the film, and [General Nutrition
Centers](/wiki/General_Nutrition_Centers "General Nutrition Centers") used the
title character as a role model for strength training.[78]
[Hasbro](/wiki/Hasbro "Hasbro") created the toy line, which they released on
May 3, 2008,[79] while [Sega](/wiki/Sega "Sega") released a [video
game](/wiki/The_Incredible_Hulk_\(2008_video_game\) "The Incredible Hulk
\(2008 video game\)") on June 5, 2008.[80] The film was promoted in an episode
of _[American Gladiators](/wiki/American_Gladiators_\(2008_TV_series\)
"American Gladiators \(2008 TV series\)")_ on June 9, 2008, which was hosted
by [Hulk Hogan](/wiki/Hulk_Hogan "Hulk Hogan") and featured [Lou
Ferrigno](/wiki/Lou_Ferrigno "Lou Ferrigno").[81]

Following the edit dispute, Universal's Adam Fogleson and Norton planned a
promotional tour which would avoid constant media interviews and therefore
uncomfortable questions. He attended the premiere, took part in a _[Jimmy
Kimmel Live!](/wiki/Jimmy_Kimmel_Live! "Jimmy Kimmel Live!")_ sketch and would
also promote the film in Japan.[45] However, during the film's release he
chose to do charity work in Africa.[82]

### Home
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Incredible_Hulk_\(film\)&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Home media")]

_The Incredible Hulk_ was released on [Blu-ray](/wiki/Blu-ray "Blu-ray") and
[DVD](/wiki/DVD "DVD") on October 21, 2008. It includes behind-the-scenes
featurettes, audio commentary, deleted scenes, and an alternate
opening.[83][84] The film was number one in sales when released on DVD and
Blu-ray on October 21, 2008, in the United States (having been available in
the United Kingdom since October 13). There are widescreen and fullscreen
single-disc editions; a three-disc special edition; and a two-disc Blu-ray
package. The first disc contains an audio commentary by Leterrier and Roth,
while the second comes with special features and deleted scenes, and the third
with a [digital copy](/wiki/Digital_Copy "Digital Copy") of the film. The Blu-
ray edition compresses the content of the first two DVDs onto one, while the
second disc contains the digital copy.

The film was also collected in a 10-disc [box set](/wiki/Box_set "Box set")
titled "[Marvel Cinematic Universe: Phase One – Avengers
Assembled](/wiki/List_of_Marvel_Cinematic_Universe_films#Home_Media "List of
Marvel Cinematic Universe films")" which includes all of the [Phase
One](/wiki/List_of_Marvel_Cinematic_Universe_films#Phase_One "List of Marvel
Cinematic Universe films") films in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.[85] It was
released by [Walt Disney Studios Home
Entertainment](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Studios_Home_Entertainment "Walt Disney
Studios Home Entertainment") on April 2, 2013.[86]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Incredible_Hulk_\(film\)&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Incredible_Hulk_\(film\)&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Box office")]

_The Incredible Hulk_ earned $134.8 million in North America, as well as
$128.6 million internationally for a worldwide total of $263.4 million.[3] The
film, even though it barely passed its predecessor, and only equalled it if
the smaller budget of the first film is taken into account, is still
considered successful. Entertainment analyst David Davis told _[The Hollywood
Reporter](/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter "The Hollywood Reporter")_ , "The first
Hulk had such high expectations after the [NBC Universal](/wiki/NBC_Universal
"NBC Universal") merger and was supposed to be critical favorite Ang Lee's
breakout commercial blockbuster. Then with the new Hulk film, Marvel was able
to underplay the importance of the success after the great success of _Iron
Man_ this summer. So the new one overdelivered, relative to its
underpromise."[87]

#### North
America[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Incredible_Hulk_\(film\)&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: North America")]

In its opening weekend, the film grossed $55.4 million in 3,505 theaters in
the United States and Canada, ranking No. 1 at the box office.[88] The
previous film earned $62.2 million in its opening weekend, but dropped 70% in
its second weekend. The second film by comparison, dropped 60% in its second
weekend.[89] Behind _[Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver
Surfer](/wiki/Fantastic_Four:_Rise_of_the_Silver_Surfer "Fantastic Four: Rise
of the Silver Surfer")_ , it was the second-highest gross for a film released
over a [Father's Day](/wiki/Father%27s_Day "Father's Day") weekend.[90] This
surpassed industry expectations of a $45 million opening, following the
disappointing response to the 2003 film. Universal believed [word of
mouth](/wiki/Word_of_mouth "Word of mouth") would contribute to the film
breaking even eventually.[2]

#### Outside North
America[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Incredible_Hulk_\(film\)&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Outside North America")]

It also opened in thirty-eight other countries, adding $31 million to the
total opening. The film outgrossed the 2003 film in South Korea, while its
openings in [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico") and Russia created records for
Universal.[91] The film grossed 24 million [yuan](/wiki/Renminbi "Renminbi")
(roughly $3.4 million) in its Chinese opening on August 26, outgrossing the
previous film's overall gross of ten million yuan.[92]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Incredible_Hulk_\(film\)&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Critical response")]

The [review aggregator](/wiki/Review_aggregator "Review aggregator") website
[Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes") reported a 67%
approval rating with an average rating of 6.2/10 based on 225 reviews. The
website's consensus reads, "_The Incredible Hulk_ may not be quite the
smashing success that fans of Marvel's raging behemoth might hope for, but it
offers more than enough big green action to make up for its occasionally puny
narrative."[93] [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic") gave the film an
average score of 61 out of 100, based on 38 reviews. The site characterized
reviews as "generally favorable".[94] A [CinemaScore](/wiki/CinemaScore
"CinemaScore") poll indicated the majority of viewers were male and graded the
film an A-, and 82% of them had seen the 2003 film.[95]

Todd McCarthy of _[Variety](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\) "Variety
\(magazine\)")_ said, "what seemed, in theory, the least-necessary revival of
a big screen superhero emerges as perfectly solid summer action fare in _The
Incredible Hulk_." He emphasized "it's all par-for-the-course cinematic
demolition and destruction, staged efficiently and with a hint of enthusiasm,"
and "penned with sporadic wit [...] Visuals lean toward the dark and murky,
but editing by three—actually six—hands is fleet, and Craig Armstrong's ever-
present score is simultaneously bombastic and helpfully supportive of the
action. Effects are in line with pic's generally pro but not inspired
achievements."[96] Rene Rodriguez of _[The Miami
Herald](/wiki/The_Miami_Herald "The Miami Herald")_ applauded that the film
"does a lot of things [Ang] Lee's _Hulk_ didn't: It's lighter and faster-
paced, it's funnier and it embraces (instead of ignoring) the 1970s TV series
that furthered the character's popularity".[97] Mark Rahner of _[The Seattle
Times](/wiki/The_Seattle_Times "The Seattle Times")_ wrote that, "The relaunch
of Marvel's green goliath is an improvement over director Ang Lee's ponderous
2003 _Hulk_ in nearly every way – except that the actual Hulk still looks
scarcely better than something from a video game, and he still barely
talks".[98] [Lou Lumenick](/wiki/Lou_Lumenick "Lou Lumenick") of the _[New
York Post](/wiki/New_York_Post "New York Post")_ said, "What lingers in my
memory ... is the lengthy, essentially animated climactic battle between the
Hulk and the Abomination on the streets and rooftops of Harlem, and an earlier
showdown between the title creature and the U.S. Army, which is deploying
high-tech weapons including sound-wave cannons. These are expertly staged by
director Louis Leterrier, who disposes of the backstory under the opening
credits and wraps up the whole thing in twenty-four minutes less than [Ang]
Lee took".[99] [Roger Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert "Roger Ebert") was not a fan of
the film stating, "_The Incredible Hulk_ is no doubt an ideal version of the
Hulk saga for those who found Ang Lee's _Hulk_ too talky, or dare I say, too
thoughtful. But not for me. It sidesteps the intriguing aspects of Hulkdom and
spends way too much time in, dare I say, noisy and mindless action
sequences."[100]

Conversely, [Christy Lemire](/wiki/Christy_Lemire "Christy Lemire") of the
_[Associated Press](/wiki/Associated_Press "Associated Press")_ found that
"the inevitable comparisons to _Iron Man_ , Marvel Studios' first blockbuster
this summer, serve as a glaring reminder of what this Hulk lacks: wit and
heart. Despite the presence of Edward Norton, an actor capable of going just
as deep as Robert Downey Jr., we don't feel a strong sense of Bruce Banner's
inner conflict".[101] [A.O. Scott](/wiki/A.O._Scott "A.O. Scott") of _[The New
York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ opined, "'The
Adequate Hulk' would have been a more suitable title. There are some big,
thumping fights and a few bright shards of pop-cultural wit, but for the most
part this movie seems content to aim for the generic mean".[102] [David
Ansen](/wiki/David_Ansen "David Ansen") of _[Newsweek](/wiki/Newsweek
"Newsweek")_ wrote, "Leterrier has style, he's good with action and he's eager
to give the audience its money's worth of bone-crunching battles. Still, once
the movie leaves the atmospheric Brazilian settings, nothing in this "Hulk"
sinks in deeply: its familiar genre pleasures are all on the surface. ... The
movie's scene stealer is Tim Blake Nelson, making a comically welcome third
act appearance as the unethical but madly enthusiastic scientist Samuel
Sterns".[103]

The film was nominated for best superhero film at the 2008 [National Movie
Awards](/wiki/National_Movie_Awards "National Movie Awards") and for Best
Science Fiction Film at the [Saturn Awards](/wiki/Saturn_Award "Saturn
Award"), but lost to _[The Dark Knight](/wiki/The_Dark_Knight_\(film\) "The
Dark Knight \(film\)")_ and _Iron Man_ , respectively.[104][105]

##
Future[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Incredible_Hulk_\(film\)&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Future")]

Further information: [List of Marvel Cinematic Universe
films](/wiki/List_of_Marvel_Cinematic_Universe_films "List of Marvel Cinematic
Universe films")

On a potential sequel, Norton said, "The whole thing was to envision it in
multiple parts. We left a lot out on purpose. [_The Incredible Hulk_ is]
definitely intended as chapter one."[14] Leterrier made the film's final shot
of Banner ambiguous; the thought being if there is a sequel, it would mean
Banner finally masters control over his anger; if there is not a sequel, the
shot indicates instead that he becomes a menace in _The Avengers_.[106]
Leterrier had also intended for a scene in the credits showing Blonsky, human
once more, imprisoned and chained in a box.[107] The character of Samuel
Sterns, played by [Tim Blake Nelson](/wiki/Tim_Blake_Nelson "Tim Blake
Nelson"), was introduced to set him up as a villain in a possible future film,
where he would become the Leader.[20][108] Aaron Sims, the lead designer on
_The Incredible Hulk_ , also took time to work on concepts for the
Leader.[109] Nelson is "signed on" to reprise the role.[110] [Ty
Burrell](/wiki/Ty_Burrell "Ty Burrell") wants to portray the superpowered Doc
Samson faithfully to the comics.[110]

Leterrier and Roth were originally contracted to return. Leterrier also stated
Norton was not signed on,[111] but in October 2008, Hurd stated that Norton
was contracted to reprise the role.[112] The film had outgrossed its
predecessor and Universal indicated interest in a sequel,[113] though
Leterrier believed a sequel would not be made because of the film's box office
return.[114] Feige said the film met Marvel's expectations and that Hulk would
return, but after the crossover.[115] Hurd was not concerned that a sequel may
not be produced until at least 2012, citing the positive reception to the film
and having produced the _[Terminator](/wiki/Terminator_\(franchise\)
"Terminator \(franchise\)")_ series, the second and third film of which had a
12-year gap.[112] Tim Roth confirmed that Marvel had signed him for three more
films.[116] Leterrier, after having previously said he did not want to direct
a sequel,[117] said in late 2009 he had changed his mind and was now
amenable.[118]

[Mark Ruffalo](/wiki/Mark_Ruffalo "Mark Ruffalo") began his role as Banner /
Hulk in _The Avengers_ , after Feige said he chose not to bring back
Norton.[119][120] In October 2014, Norton claimed he chose never to play Hulk
again because he "wanted more diversity" with his career, and did not want to
be associated with only one character.[121] In April 2012, despite Ruffalo
being on board to play the Hulk in the sequel, Feige confirmed to
[Collider](/wiki/Collider.com "Collider.com") that Marvel had no plans at that
time to film another Hulk film.[122] In a Q&A session, Feige and Ruffalo
confirmed that discussions are underway to produce another Hulk film due to
the positive audience response to Ruffalo's performance in _The
Avengers_.[123] In September 2012, Feige, while exploring all possible story
options for a sequel film, including a film based on the "[Planet
Hulk](/wiki/Planet_Hulk "Planet Hulk")" and "[World War
Hulk](/wiki/World_War_Hulk "World War Hulk")" storylines, stated, "everything
[in terms of stories from the comics] is on the table. Do I think Hulk can
carry a movie and be as entertaining as he was in _Avengers_? I do believe
that. I do believe he absolutely could. We certainly are not even going to
attempt that until _Avengers 2_. So there's a lot of time to think about
it."[124]

In June 2014, Ruffalo said he believed the studio might be considering doing a
new standalone Hulk film, saying, "I think they are, for the first time,
entertaining the idea of it. When we did _The Avengers_ it was basically
'No!', and now there is some consideration for it. But there's still nothing
definitive, not even a skeletal version of what it would be."[125] In July,
Feige stated that the studio was not considering a "Planet Hulk" film at that
time, due to wanting to feature Ruffalo's Banner in the film. However, he did
not rule out a story that saw the Hulk and Banner end up in space and
explained why a solo Hulk film did not occur in [Phase
Two](/wiki/List_of_Marvel_Cinematic_Universe_films#Phase_Two "List of Marvel
Cinematic Universe films") of the MCU by saying, "After the first _Avengers_ ,
Iron Man had his own movie, Thor had his own movie, Captain America had his
own movie, and Widow and Fury were in _[The Winter
Soldier](/wiki/Captain_America:_The_Winter_Soldier "Captain America: The
Winter Soldier")_. So it was really about, frankly, _saving_ somebody so that
the only place you could get Hulk between _Avengers_ movies is the _next_
_Avengers_ movie, so [director Joss Whedon] could continue to play with that
in [_Avengers: Age of Ultron_]. Where we go after that, we'll see."[126] In
October 2014, again on a solo film, Feige said, "We'll see. We'd love to do
it, we'd love to find the place to put it, but right now, Hulk will be
appearing, with his friends, in their [[Phase
Three](/wiki/List_of_Marvel_Cinematic_Universe_films#Phase_Three "List of
Marvel Cinematic Universe films")] films."[127]

In April 2015, Ruffalo said Universal holding the distribution rights to Hulk
films may be an obstacle to releasing a future Hulk standalone film[128] and
reiterated this in October 2015,[129] and July 2017.[130] Marvel reacquired
the film rights for the character, but Universal retained the distribution
rights for _The Incredible Hulk_ as well as the [right of first
refusal](/wiki/Right_of_first_refusal "Right of first refusal") to distribute
future Hulk films.[131] According to _The Hollywood Reporter_ , a potential
reason why Marvel has not reacquired the film distribution rights to the Hulk
as they did with [Paramount Pictures](/wiki/Paramount_Pictures "Paramount
Pictures") for the Iron Man, Thor, and Captain America films is because
Universal holds the [theme park](/wiki/Universal_Parks_%26_Resorts "Universal
Parks & Resorts") rights to several Marvel characters that Marvel's parent
company, [Disney](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company "The Walt Disney Company"),
wants for its own [theme parks](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Parks_and_Resorts "Walt
Disney Parks and Resorts").[132] In December 2015, Ruffalo stated that the
strained relationship between Marvel and Universal may be another obstacle to
releasing a future standalone Hulk film.[133] The following month, he
indicated that the lack of a standalone Hulk film allowed the character to
play a more prominent role in _[Thor: Ragnarok](/wiki/Thor:_Ragnarok "Thor:
Ragnarok")_ , _[Avengers: Infinity War](/wiki/Avengers:_Infinity_War
"Avengers: Infinity War")_ , and [the latter's untitled
sequel](/wiki/Untitled_Avengers_film "Untitled Avengers film"), stating,
"We’ve worked a really interesting arc into _Thor[: Ragnarok]_ , _Avengers[:
Infinity War]_ , and [the latter's sequel] for Banner that I think will – when
it’s all added up – will feel like a Hulk movie, a standalone movie."[134]

  1. **Jump up ^** According to Leterrier, the film takes place about five years since Banner first transformed.[4] The events of the film also take place simultaneously with the events of _[Iron Man 2](/wiki/Iron_Man_2 "Iron Man 2")_ (2010) and _[Thor](/wiki/Thor_\(film\) "Thor \(film\)")_ (2011),[5] the former of which is set six months after the events of _[Iron Man](/wiki/Iron_Man_\(2008_film\) "Iron Man \(2008 film\)")_ (2008).[6]
